draw_res.title: Drawing
draw_res.header: Expand your creative skillset with Drawing
draw_res.description: Want to start drawing for fun or take your craft to the next level? Explore our online drawing classes and learn pencil drawing, figure drawing, cartoon drawing, character drawing for cartoons and anime, illustration, sketching, shading and more. Take an overview course on the fundamentals of drawing or zero in on an area you’d like to improve with a specialized course. We’ve got tons of options to get — and keep — you going.

items.title: The Secrets to Drawing
items.headline: A comprehensive video and ebook course designed for people wanting to learn the core concepts of drawing.
objectives_summary: By the end of this course, the student will have a strong understanding of the core concepts of drawing including materials, processes, and devices.

items.title: Art Fundamentals: Foundations of Painting and Drawing Course

visible_instructors.title: Scott Harris
visible_instructors.name: Scott
visible_instructors.job_title: Art Director, Author, Instructor - ASI, DAS School of Art

objectives_summary: How To Understand the Core Principles of Creating Art
Learn about Shape, Form and Detail in Art
How to Draw and Paint with Looseness, Energy and Confidence

Learn the 5 elements of shading
How to sketch complicated object using simple shapes

items.title: Building Confidence Through Drawing: Art for Beginners
items.headline: 22 Drawing Lessons for Beginners. Course is perfect for engaging after-school activities or homeschool art projects.
objectives_summary: Create 22 delightful cartoon drawings!
Engage in an activity that has been shown to improve self-confidence and boost self-esteem.
Participate in an activity that cultivates critical thinking skills, develops hand-eye coordination, and encourages self-expression.

items.title: Art for Kids & Beginners: 15 Easy Drawing & Painting Lessons
items.headline: Students Will Learn How to Draw & Watercolor Paint 15 Cute Animals Step-By-Step. For Beginners of All Ages and Abilities
objectives_summary: Create 15 Magnificent Watercolor Animal Paintings.
Participate in an activity that cultivates critical thinking skills, develops hand-eye coordination, and encourages self-expression.
Apply the knowledge gained in this course to create unique masterpieces.

items.title: Draw Islamic Geometric Patterns With A Compass And Ruler
items.headline: Learn to Construct, Outline, Tile And Interlace Five Different Patterns.
objectives_summary: Construct four different islamic geometric patterns
Outline the pattern having constructed an underlying grid
Tile eightfold and sixfold patterns.

items.title: The Ultimate Drawing Course - Beginner to Advanced
items.headline: Learn the #1 most important building block of all art, Drawing. This course will teach you how to draw like a pro!
objectives_summary: Draw objects out of your head
Draw realistic light and shadow
Understand the fundamentals of art

items.title: The Art & Science of Drawing / BASIC SKILLS
items.headline: Drawing is not a talent. It's a skill anyone can learn.
objectives_summary: How to draw any shape.
How to observe and analyze any subject.
How to draw any form by breaking it down into basic shapes before adding dark lines.

items.title: How to Draw and Sketch for Absolute Beginners pt 1
items.headline: Learn the Basics of Sketching and Drawing
objectives_summary: By the end of this course you will be able to draw almost anything
The correct way to use reference
Draw what they see and observe

items.title: The Art & Science of Drawing / DYNAMIC MARK MAKING
items.headline: Create compelling drawings using expressive mark making.
objectives_summary: How to use the pencil to create a wide range of expressive and engaging lines marks.
How to infuse your line work with emotion that truly connect with a viewer.
How to draw objects in a way that give the viewer a sense of what it feels like to the touch.

items.title: The Art & Science of Drawing / FORM & SPACE
items.headline: Learn to draw in 3-Dimensions
objectives_summary: How draw the foundational volumes, spheres, cylinders and cubes, in any orientation in space.
How to break any form down into basic volumes and in doing so, understand how to draw them 3-Dimensionally.
How to draw objects properly in perspective.

items.title: The Art & Science of Drawing / MEASURING & PROPORTION
items.headline: Dramatically increase the accuracy of your drawings.
objectives_summary: How to determine the proportions of any subject
How to use the pencil to transfer accurate information from their subject to their drawing surface.
How to combine a variety of measuring techniques to accurately measure any subject.

results.content:
Very basic yet fundamental. Not a lot of practice, mostly examples. I recommend this course to those who are making their very first steps with SQL. Be aware that the content is heavily duplicated for 2 platforms: PostgreSQL and MS Server SQL so the total content of the course to actually learn is half of the hours than those in the description.
Pros:
1. The instructors are clear and succinct.
2. Good basic tips that will save you later on.
3. Real world databases to work with to get a solid impression.

Cons:
1. Does not cover what you need for an actual interview.
2. Imoprtant (NOT advanced) features of SQL like "Having", "In/Not in", Aggregation Functions, Triggers, Functions, Views and Security are not covered.
3. No real problems to solve, simple quizes with obvious answers so there is no real "doing".

The course is outdated, and the vary basics of the work environment are not explained, so you might encounter a lot of technical problems, but hey, that's just the way it is :).

Overall, the course is useful to get an overall picture of the subject.

results.content: Sullivan's book, "Line: An Art Study" made me fall in love with line and Mr. Eviston's explorations of it only add to my love affair! Yes, lines do have a psychology attached to them just as does color, and critical decisions are made in any art project about where, how, and when to use and place lines as well as what characteristics they are to have. These notions are wonderfully explored in this course, especially in the Tactile Line and Atmospherics classes. My favorite is the drawing sequence for a rock. I think they are difficult to draw, and Mr. Eviston demonstrates some strategies that have been helpful and problem-solving for it. He has created more classes, and I look forward to advancing my skills in the next! Dave in California

results.content:
Excellent course. I first took the Simon Sez IT MS Project 2013 Bundle and really enjoyed the course. I learned a great deal from it. Since I liked it so much I decided to try the MS Excel 2013 course. I was quite pleased to find that Toby Arnott was the instructor again as he did a fantastic job with the Project courses. A couple of things to note with this course... 
I have more experience with Excel than I had with Project so much (though by no means all) of what is in the Beginner course is review. Fortunately the Udemy interface allows me to play it at 2x speed to get through it quicker without missing anything interesting. Your brain gets used to the speed pretty quickly and before you know it you don't even notice that it is faster than normal. Similarly, since all MS Office products share the ribbon interface and Office Backstage, most of that is similar to what I saw in the MS Project course. If you are taking several MS Office courses you will see some redundancy but you can speed past it or use it as review. 
As I got into the advanced portion of the course I found that it went beyond what I typically need to use Excel for. While I need to be able to use some other products such as MS Project or MS OneNote at an advanced level, I’m probably fine with using Excel at an intermediate level. I’m not a statistician or a finance and accounting guy and some of the material was interesting but not something I will typically use in my daily job. That said, for those who need that, I think it was covered well. I recommend the course.

results.content: A wealth of useful information and critical concepts are presented in this course by Mr. Eviston that will intrigue, challenge, and even dazzle beginners and experienced artists alike! As has been true in the other courses I have taken with him, his style of presentation is slow and methodical. He demonstrates each tool and technique while clearly describing each as he works. He gives many opportunities to practice each, but encourages students to do more and more of the practice sets to deeply embed these basic skills into place. Section 2, Day 3: Beyond the Box was my favorite and most challenging. I thought I understood how boxes in space respond to perspective, but when I started drawing them myself, I often got confused or just lost in the process. A quick rewind of the lesson helped me find my confusion, correct my image, and then move to another. It took me six or seven times of drawing many boxes before I finally understood and could see how to use the techniques to create boxes in space and in perspective. The ending project is fun to do because he has found a way to put all of the skills in this and his earlier courses to work to produce a satisfying final drawing. There are more courses in this series, and I cannot wait to study more with him!  Dave in California

results.content: Thanks a lot Chandra for the awesome AWS certification courses. I had no knowledge of AWS when I bought your courses back in late 2019. After 2-3 months of rigorous preparation,  I mustered the courage and took the test(SAA-C01) last week(03/09/20) and scored 940/1000. All credit goes to you. I appreciate the quickness and frequency at which you update your courses to keep up with what's happening on the AWS side and the clarity and simplicity in all your presentations/videos. Without the courses, I think, it would have taken me more time to prepare and appear for the test. Thank you not just for the courses and the score but also for making me feel like an expert in most of the AWS services and best practices.

results.content:
This course offers an acceptable overview of many data science tools on real data. If you're looking for a beginner's primer on the material, this course may be for you. If you're used to Indian English, then the teacher's voice shouldn't be an issue. What could be improved is focusing on and diving deeper into data. There were some lectures that focused on importing, for example, data from the Boston real estate area, manipulating it a bit and the lecture ended. Then, in the lecture immediately after, the data the teacher was using as an example was chemical compositions of glass; the video after that bounced to another set of data; eventually, we returned to the Boston data, then shot off to recurring sets of data. The teacher is quite knowledgeable in the material and the processes; I felt that she could have taken a set of data and used it longer from start to finish. 

As I said, this is a good start. Take notes of key terms and concepts and use this video as a platform into other courses on those key terms and concepts. 

Nevertheless, a big thanks to the instructor for taking the time to put together this course.

results.content: Still another "award winning" course by Mr. Eviston that contains information and skills that should be in every artist's tool box. I have used all of these techniques and find them to be not only helpful, but also powerful evaluation techniques for those times when I am putting something I see on paper which I think is correct and then use one of the measuring tools to show me just how far off I have guessed. I have read some comments from students in other courses who do not want to be bothered with measuring, claiming it is too time consuming and not fun. My experience is just the opposite! With just a few practice sessions, I have easily understood the mechanics of the measuring strategies, and almost automatically reach for them when drawing almost anything. They only take a moment or two to use and adjust a drawing, and I find that I enjoy seeing the measured results which now look correct. I think that contour drawing is next in the sequence, and I know it will be exciting to study!

results.content:
Update: Great course in all - Helped me pass my exam yesterday

Very clear in explaining concepts, lecture is thorough followed by hands on to enforce what was explained in lecture.  A good well packaged course so far. Would certainly recommend for students preparing for AWS Solution Architect - Professional certification

Update : Domain2 - This is all over the place without any direction. This section looks more like collection of modules from other courses. Though still provides useful information, it lacks structure. Not sure if it will help with Certification exam.

Update: Domain3 : Looks a bit outdated, this section talks about sending a USB drive to AWS, which has been discontinued for a while, Rest looks good with demonstrations

Update Domain4: Good information on EC2 types, which is  usually  mentioned as footnotes, Zeal takes time to explain the finer points and reinforces with demonstration.
results.content_html:

results.content: There is a lot of content in this course with detailed explanations on complex functions. Still, there was no discussion on any practical use of say a fortune 500 company using this in their business because they wouldn't do that. They would contract with say Oracle or IBM because their systems have expanded capacity as well as continuity built into that kind of investment. I am glad for the few things I have taken away to be useful, but still am not sure what I can do with the rest. Lastly, I need to mention the instructor is very good at explaining the concepts.

results.content:
Quite good. However he DOES give us exercises sometimes that I can't figure out, only to find out his solution contains things we have not gone over at all yet. That is very frustrating. Its happened multiple times, most notably with vlookup. We were just expected to have previous knowledge of this function I guess? But there were other ones too. 

It's not a bad course though, I'm learning a lot and I still recommend it

Edit: So I just finished the course.
Some more complaints I had were it would be nice to have more exercises later in the course. Especially the last Section, that's the best way to solidify the learnings he taught us. 
I also would have liked to know how to create or update charts with VBA, but I think if I searched for some online tutorials I probably wouldn't be too lost figuring it out.
Also I did almost the entire course with captions (no audio), they could be a bit better.. a lot of it didn't make any sense, a lot of times I was just guessing what he was saying.
Overall I feel like it was well worth the money for this course, I feel like I could actually go into work and design some interesting things. 
Glad I purchased the course, thanks for teaching me. Thumbs up

results.content: I found this course to be great at covering the basics on a surface level in understanding on the textbook meaning of each of these fundamentals, however I was disappointed at how short/brief each section was covered. Given the cost of this course I'd hoped each subject would have more in-depth examples and, ultimately, more learning tools/drawing prompts to make the course more engaging, but found it to have less substance as the course went on. The warm-up activity in the beginning of this course was fantastic- it would be great if more exercises like that one were added, along with more visual examples of painted work.

results.content: Loved this course, and would have been a no-brainer recommendation if I had taken this several years ago. Unfortunately, the course has not been updated as well as it should have been in terms of ES6 content. There are a few ES6 lectures, but they are not of the same high quality as the rest of the series. Personally, I was really excited for the Promises/Async/Await section but it was a huge let-down and left me even more confused than before. The rest of the course is wonderful and a must-watch, however.

results.content:
I was looking for a front-end web development course and this course not only taught me how to develop websites, but also web design which is very valuable especially in case I would be freelancing one day. 
There were only a couple things I struggled to make work (using PHP locally, and some code that was broken on my end), but I found workarounds in QA forums so it wasn't a big deal. 
SPOILER alert: Brad is a likeable fella. He will keep you motivated.

results.content:
Originally, I took this course in order to help demysify and relearn some of the aspects used with converting a Design and completing the final Developement phase. In the past I found myself becomming complacent using tools like Dreamweaver and have eventually shied away from coding since the actual design and finished look is way more inspiring to me. However, I eventually realized that I really needed to better understand this process.

It is great that Brad has so much knowledge in the entire realm of Website building that he can actually teach it for 30+ hours! 

Since completing this course, I will definitely revisit from time to time (especially if I get stuck on a project!).

This is the most inclusive and "all incompassing course" that I have found so far regarding Website building and really provides a full picture of the entire process!

results.content: I took the course on Tableau that SDS put out and LOVED it, so I was pretty excited for this course, but I was let down pretty heavily. I started off with the section about SQL, but I was quickly disappointed when I found out it is very difficult (if not impossible) to do on Mac. Now, it is not the SDS Team's fault that it does not work for Mac, but there was never any mention of this issue in the videos. I found comments from other people dating back 3 years expressing similar thoughts, but no changes have been made. In the section about building and analyzing models, there is a portion where you use Excel to analyze the model we built in Gretl. There are some Excel short-cuts used that were not explained, and it was VERY difficult to complete the tasks without knowing those short cuts. Again, comments from people dating back 3 years express similar ideas, but no actual changes have been made. The section on Tableau was good, but as mentioned previously I have already done the Tableau course, so I did not really learn anything new.
results.content_html: I took the course on Tableau that SDS put out and LOVED it, so I was pretty excited for this course, but I was let down pretty heavily. I started off with the section about SQL, but I was quickly disappointed when I found out it is very difficult (if not impossible) to do on Mac. Now, it is not the SDS Team's fault that it does not work for Mac, but there was never any mention of this issue in the videos. I found comments from other people dating back 3 years expressing similar thoughts, but no changes have been made. In the section about building and analyzing models, there is a portion where you use Excel to analyze the model we built in Gretl. There are some Excel short-cuts used that were not explained, and it was VERY difficult to complete the tasks without knowing those short cuts. Again, comments from people dating back 3 years express similar ideas, but no actual changes have been made. The section on Tableau was good, but as mentioned previously I have already done the Tableau course, so I did not really learn anything new.

results.content: I had various mechanistic tasks to do quite frequently in my job, which require hundreds of clicks and mouse operations if done manually (e.g., Excel files, pdfs, and text files). Before this course, I was aware that these tasks could be automated with Python, but I did not know the relevant Python libraries that can do so (as there are so many possibilities, and some libraries are too complicated or limited). This course provided various practical examples and suggested libraries for achieving those tasks. I have already applied some of examples given in the course to my personal needs, and indeed, I have less boring, mechanistic tasks on my todos ... and my mouse hand is happier, too. I wish had taken this course sooner.

Before writing my review thank you Jose for making such a great course.Project were extremely helpfull, I hope your Django course also gets more projects like this.

Before starting this course I was a complete beginner. After completing this course in 9 weeks(avg. 3 - 4 hours a day) I have understood everything that was given in the course. I really recommend this course.

The reason why I gave 4.5 stars is some concepts were just rushed quickly as I understood what Jose was doing but didn't really understand the logic behind so had to do lots of google search.

I know If he spent time on explaining every logic behind each line course would never finish.

Also I wish OOP lectures had more exercises just like Methods and Functions.

Before taking this course If you feel like you want to go to course and you dont want to  study online, I wouldn't really recommend that.Because the best part of this course was whatever I couldn't find online or couldn't understand It was either asked or Jose's teachers were responding my questions immidiately.

results.content:
Because it is organized in a comprehensible way. The instructor's voice pitch and approach are perfect in my opinion.
But after I did the exams for the PCEP-30-01, PCEP-30-02 I discovered that there are some basic topics that were not covered even after reaching chapter 12 such as and not limited to: 
- Function(variable, end="") this "end" thing at the end.
- Bin(), AND, OR, |. the base of the binary is 2. (The Whole Topic)
- Within a  a while loop or an if statements > continue to skip that iteration.
- I have passed both exams and have wrote some code of my own but still I find it very difficult to think my way through complicated multi levels while or for loops which is how the you get tested. (an advise on this would be really really appreciated what am I missing.)
-The whole Array union intersection topic, I failed every question I faced on it.
results.content_html:
Because it is organized in a comprehensible way. The instructor's voice pitch and approach are perfect in my opinion.
But after I did the exams for the PCEP-30-01, PCEP-30-02 I discovered that there are some basic topics that were not covered even after reaching chapter 12 such as and not limited to:
- Function(variable, end="") this "end" thing at the end.
- Bin(), AND, OR, |. the base of the binary is 2. (The Whole Topic)
- Within a a while loop or an if statements > continue to skip that iteration.
- I have passed both exams and have wrote some code of my own but still I find it very difficult to think my way through complicated multi levels while or for loops which is how the you get tested. (an advise on this would be really really appreciated what am I missing.)
-The whole Array union intersection topic, I failed every question I faced on it.

results.content: For a beginner that is interested in how to use Python in real world applications, this course is a must. The Desktop App and the Web app projects allow to familiarize with the true use of programming. Anyway, since most fundamental coding topics are introduced very rapidly, it might not be a course for Absolute Beginners (you should have at least some general knowledge on the main structures of coding such as loops, conditionals, etc.).
results.content_html: For a beginner that is interested in how to use Python in real world applications, this course is a must. The Desktop App and the Web app projects allow to familiarize with the true use of programming. results.content: I really enjoyed this course and learned a ton! Some lessons force you to seek solutions in the Q/A because the way things are done constantly changes in the tech world, but that can be part of the learning experience because problem solving is a huge part of becoming a developer! The final project uses a lot of packages and outside resources which means that 5 years from now you would probably have to update a lot of the code for the project to make it continue to work. Packages and outside resources have updates and newer versions constantly. This means you have to stay up to date with them and so does your code!

I think the strongest side of this course was to not learn syntax and oblige to write ANN using numpy. It was totally a new experience for me and finally allowed me to understand basic concepts.

ALL of the code in this course is meant to be an exercise. Don't cheat by just watching the lectures straight through!

results.content:
I am a statistics graduate student and when I started this course I had zero knowledge about R and coding in general. Throughout my first semester, I really struggled with coding and I'm one of those people who just thought I would never really get it no matter what I tried. However, that all changed over the course of the school year as I learned R on my own and with the help of this course. By the time I was done with my second semester I actually felt pretty competent in R. Not to the point where I can just look at a problem and instantly know how to code it (like some R wizards can do), but to the point where I actually feel comfortable explaining how to do lots of things in R to other people who are just starting and being able to figure out moderately complex problems on my own or with minimal google searching for function syntax.  

This course was an absolutely critical component of my learning experience. It made me realize that you don't need to memorize everything about R, you just need to understand what tools R gives you and then frame your problem in those terms. Kirill is an excellent teacher and he really gets to the meat of each skill and technique he is trying to show you in each lesson. He doesn't gloss over things, he explains them in basic terms and builds from there. He seems to have a good intuition for what you're thinking as he explains things, too. There were many times where I would be following his lesson and ask myself a question only to have him bring it up a moment later and explain it fully. 

If you do buy his course, I would advise you to do the lessons in chunks and make sure you really get what was taught before moving on to the next ones. Most importantly, go back and reference lessons when needed. I did this countless times and it really helped to reinforce my learning. If I was stuck on a particular part of a problem in real life I would think "wait, I saw something like this in the tutorials" and then I would go back and watch that lesson. Every time I did this it helped me to better understand the reasoning behind it instead of just quickly googling an answer that I only half understand.

So, in summary, this course helped me out tremendously as both a straight up tutorial with applicable content and also as a valuable reference that I could always go back to when needed to ensure I understood why certain functions or methods worked the way they do. I highly recommend this course!

results.content:
The course only requires of you to have a text editor but that won't cut it. You do need to have HTML, CSS and JS knowledge unless you want to use this course as a cookbook. In that case, it will serve you well. Although the instructor explains HTML and CSS in greater detail than JS, he still uses parts that weren't covered or, at least, talked about in previous lessons. I regard this course as practice after you've learned the web trinity and you want to practice it on a webpage. 

If you've never touched JavaScript, the code you type will do its thing but you won't know why it is used or how it actually works. Directing students to job sites like Upwork or Freelancer with only the knowledge gathered during this course is a great mistake unless you have decided to do some background reading about HTML, CSS and JS on MDN, W3Schools or another reference site, and made a couple of websites yourself. The most useful part for me in this course was figuring out how to use Bootstrap framework.

results.content:
This course was great, we were introduced to a whole bunch of different concepts and created a webpage that included many optimizations.
That being said, we didn't go deep in any of those concepts, and merely wrote the code at the same time and observed the results. Many functions that were used are unexplained and are just "follow me with this" so we can see a result. I don't remember most of them nor would I be able to remember to use them if the need arise. If I need to build a similar webpage, I'll probably need to re-do the course to remember hat to use and where. There is very little practice and there are no exercises or tests to validate knowledge.
That being said, I did enjoy it, and would recommend it.

results.content:
There is a lot of information in this course but it is incredibly boring, truly a mind numbing experience. Most of this course, literally hours on hours, is spent on 13-20min lectures that just include very isolated and basic examples for the topic being explained.

It is by far the worst way to learn. Max believes otherwise but sorry this is incredibly boring. There are two projects in the course but that's really it, and you more or less just follow along rather than get challenged every step of the way. 

I do not recommend this course for beginners. Instead, pick up a project based approach and that will definitely keep you engaged.

results.content:
The good: I did learn a few things, BUT I'm a relative beginner with R, so I should have found this much more challenging. 

Bad: for an 'advanced' course, he took the slow way vs a more 'advanced' way on several lessons, such as importing all the CSV files in S4 manually, versus using lapply, dropping the ending and renaming the list with the file name. 
U3 32: should have mentioned converting time zones. 

S4: the dot operator is an 'advanced' way to refer to a directory? Seriously?
He makes reference to 'going to fast' a lot, when he doesn't. 

Do I have regrets? No. I learned a few things, but I'm pretty new to R. 
Rename this "intermediate" or advanced beginner.

results.content:
First let me say this: the things that are contained within this course are done well. He builds upon the knowledge gained from his beginner's R course in a good manner, and everything was presented in an easy to understand fashion just like his other courses.

But this course had no actual CODING. There were no end-of-section challenges (essentially homework problems) the way his beginner's R course did. If you're already an experienced coder? Okay, you may not need such exercises. But for those of us taking this course as a sequel to his beginner's R programming course, the lack of actual coding is a critical flaw.

For a newer programmer one of the best ways to learn and gain experience is to actually CODE. His beginner's course had challenges at the end of each section where you had to try to take everything you had learned and put it all together into a real, personally coded solution. Such things are very much missing in this course. It's a bare-bones information course with no actual coding.

If this course had optional homework / challenges that we can attempt ourselves along with posted solutions when we run into problems, then this course would be an easy 5/5 (and no, the two short and cursory ones near the end are not enough to count). Without that hands-on experience to help solidify my growing skills, I just can't give this course the high rating it would otherwise deserve.  Anyone coming from Kirill's beginner's course deserves more than what we got here. This course was just a Cliff's Notes reading.

results.content: Very good as usual. I like the approach of learning by doing exercises that are relevant to the real world. The course design is logical and step-by-step so that it needs an incremental effort to put in. What I hope to improve is the update to the current R version as some of the real output is not per the video. In addition, I'd love Kirill to explain a little bit more about the big-picture concept such as why we should use the list in R, as opposed to normal data frame, the way some syntax is organized, for instance - lapply(Weather, "[", 1, 7) - why the "[".

results.content:
A fun course with a very wide scope but covers off core concepts and techniques well, and gives the student a good grounding to set off and get to grips with whatever it is they want to draw. There are "homework" assignments (I never got around to joining the community, so no idea if it's still active/available) to put the learning into practice, and by the end you'll have a pile of papers that chart the progress you've made. If you're looking specifically for figure / character drawing, those about 10 hours in to an eleven hour course - you don't get to lace up your runners till you've walked a couple of laps. But by the time you get there your pencil control will be much better than it was when you started.
I'd have liked to see something around practice routines or exercises, but that's because I'm crap at self-motivation. If you want to draw, this course will teach you how to think about it and how to do it better.

results.content:
The course is very good and broad, exactly what I was looking for.

Pros:
- Quick overview of almos all ML fields, with hands-down explanations of the concepts behind them (in all but 1 case - XGBoost)

- Many resources provided, both as downloadable content and references and bibliography content

- There's active instructors in the Q&A section that can help you with issues you may have.

- Almost all content is done in both Python and R (only missing a CNN R implmentation)


Cons:
- Some content is slightly out of date, as certain libaries and packages used throughout the course have some differences in their API calls.

- There's some areas I wish were explained in more depth

- Some resources are provided as-is, with no explanation about them (only a few cases)

The course is excellent for a fast dive in ML, covering all main fileds with a variety of techniques:
- Dimensionality Reduction with PCA and LDA
- Regression & Classification with a handful of approaches. Linear, logistic, random forest, naive bayesian...
- Association Rule
- Data Clustering: k-means, SVM, 
- Neural Networks

Almost all content is explained nicely.
I did miss a lecture for the XGBoost model, or even some pointers to bibliography so I could do the research myself. It was suprising as all other sections do have at least 1 single lecture regarding the theory or concepts behind the topic covered.

Some lectures seem to drag unnecessarily. While I think it's great lecturers take their time to explain key areas and concepts, more than a few times the lecture would get stuck for 5 mins + on some area that was explained at the beginning of the course, not adding anything new.

Overall, I give it 4.5/5.
The course is very good. The negative points stand out simply because everything else is so polished. Totally recommended if you have no knowledge of ML or if, just like me, you already have some knowledge of certain areas and wish to expand your skillset AND/OR you already have knowledge of ML in either Python or R and wish to learn the other.

About the latter point, my take from the course is that certain parts of ML are much more convenient to implement in R, even if (to my opinion) R is not as straightforward as Python.

As a final note:
I'd personally recommend you already have at least some programming experience before taking the course. As I mentioned at the beginning, some parts of the course are slightly out of date. Even if they are up to date, some things may not be as straightforward as shown in the lectures. You may need to correct the code yourself, which will require you to have basic notions of object-oriented programming. You can always check the Q&A for people with the same problem as you (everyone has them at some point), or ask the question yourself if you can't find the answer or would like some more clarifications.

Farewell and, as you will hear time and time again throughout this course should you decide to enroll in it, happy machine learning.

The course is very good. The negative points stand out simply because everything else is so polished. Totally recommended if you have no knowledge of ML or if, just like me, you already have some knowledge of certain areas and wish to expand your skillset AND/OR you already have knowledge of ML in either Python or R and wish to learn the other.

About the latter point, my take from the course is that certain parts of ML are much more convenient to implement in R, even if (to my opinion) R is not as straightforward as Python.

As a final note:
I'd personally recommend you already have at least some programming experience before taking the course. As I mentioned at the beginning, some parts of the course are slightly out of date. Even if they are up to date, some things may not be as straightforward as shown in the lectures. You may need to correct the code yourself, which will require you to have basic notions of object-oriented programming. You can always check the Q&A for people with the same problem as you (everyone has them at some point), or ask the question yourself if you can't find the answer or would like some more clarifications.

Farewell and, as you will hear time and time again throughout this course should you decide to enroll in it, happy machine learning.
